abstract_summ: Depending on the realized level of contact reduction, tracing and isolation of only household contacts, or of household and non-household contacts are necessary to reduce the effective reproduction number to below 1.More specifically, we investigate how well contact tracing apps, coupled with the quarantine of identified contacts, can mitigate a spread in realistic scenarios such as a university campus, a workplace, or a high school.Interpretation: We successfully augmented contact matrices with time-use data to predict the highest impact of social distancing measures from reduced contacts when spending less time at work, school, and on social visits.Sensitivity analysis and simulations under different re-opening scenarios illustrate the differential effects that responsive contact tracing and lockdowns can have on current and second wave outbreaks.We also show that, when the number of traced contacts is small, the number of prevented transmission per traced node is even higher---although most traced individuals are healthy---than that from case isolation without contact tracing.
title_summ: An SEIR Model with Contact Tracing and Age-Structured Social Mixing for COVID-19 outbreakHeterogeneity is essential for contact tracingDifferential impacts of contact tracing and lockdowns on outbreak size in COVID-19 model applied to ChinaUsing real-world contact networks to quantify theeffectiveness of digital contact tracing and isolation strategies for Covid-19 pandemicContact Tracing Evaluation for COVID-19 Transmission during the Reopening Phase in a Rural College TownContacts in context: large-scale setting-specific social mixing matrices from the BBC Pandemic projectReproducing SARS-CoV-2 epidemics byregion-specific variables and modeling contacttracing App containmentTo isolate, or not to isolate: a theoretical framework for disease control via contact tracingIsolation and contact tracing can tip the scale to containment of COVID-19 in populations with social distancingCombining fine-scale social contact data with epidemic modelling reveals interactions between contact tracing, quarantine, testing and physical distancing for controlling COVID-19Augmenting contact matrices with time-use data for fine-grained intervention modelling of disease dynamics: A modelling analysisJoint spatio-temporal analysis of multiple response types using the hierarchical generalized transformation model with application to coronavirus disease 2019 and social distancingThe effectiveness of contact tracing in heterogeneous networksA note on community-detection (Kemeny) based testing for COVID-19Halting SARS-CoV-2 by Targeting High-Contact Individuals
title_abstract_phrases: Depending on the realized level of contact reduction, tracing and isolation of only household contacts, or of household and non-household contacts are necessary to reduce the effective reproduction number to below 1.More specifically, we investigate how well contact tracing apps, coupled with the quarantine of identified contacts, can mitigate a spread in realistic scenarios such as a university campus, a workplace, or a high school.We also show that, when the number of traced contacts is small, the number of prevented transmission per traced node is even higher---although most traced individuals are healthy---than that from case isolation without contact tracing.We fit the mathematical model to data from China on reported cases and quarantined contacts, finding that lockdowns had an overwhelming influence on outbreak size and duration, whereas contact tracing played a role in reducing peak number of infected.However, the current leading modeling framework for evaluating contact tracing is highly stylized, lacking important features and heterogeneities present in real-world contact patterns that are relevant for epidemic dynamics.
